image.altText: Troops stand scattered alone a dirt road.

items.synopsis: Israeli's defence minister tells troops gathered at the Gaza border they would soon see the Palestinian enclave "from inside", suggesting an expected ground invasion could be nearing. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli defence chief says troops will soon see Gaza 'from inside'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European Council President Charles Michel anticipates the country may have to take in tens of thousands of Palestinians fleeing war-torn Gaza. "Egypt needs support, so let's support Egypt," said Mr Michel, who will visit Egypt tomorrow to meet with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi. He will also attend a "conference on the current developments in the Middle East, Palestine and the Peace Process", according to his spokesperson. Mr Michel stressed the "challenge" posed by the potential influx of refugees into Egypt. He said he expected an "important exchange of information" on the subject at an upcoming US-EU summit in Washington. AFP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EU president says Egypt needs support to handle those fleeing Gaza

children.content: European Council President
Charles Michel
anticipates the country may have to take in tens of thousands of Palestinians fleeing war-torn Gaza.
"Egypt needs support, so let's support Egypt," said Mr Michel, who will visit Egypt tomorrow to meet with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.
He will also attend a "conference on the current developments in the Middle East, Palestine and the Peace Process", according to his spokesperson.
Mr Michel stressed the "challenge" posed by the potential influx of refugees into Egypt.
He said he expected an "important exchange of information" on the subject at an upcoming US-EU summit in Washington.
AFP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Declan Bowring, ABC Radio Sydney A Sydney-based Palestinian with family in Gaza says it's a matter of life and death for her relatives. Ramia Abdo Sultan told ABC Radio Sydney Mornings she had relatives sheltering at a UN-run school, which was taking 6,000 people despite only having capacity for 1,500 people. She says food is also scarce, with people at the shelter receiving three loaves of bread and three cups of water a day. "In my lifetime, for all I've known it, I've never seen this unfold," Ms Abdo Sultan said. "It's a situation of literally life or death for many who are surviving the massacre." Ms Abdo Sultan said she has patchy contact with her relatives who need to find solar-generated power to charge their phones. Ms Abdo Sultan says Australians who can leave Gaza have tried to exit through the Rafa crossing into Egypt but have not been able to get through multiple times. "They've tried multiple times to leave … only to wait a couple of hours and to be left with no option but to return," Ms Abdo Sultan said. "They feel like they have not had the same level of support and attention that anyone else around the world would have otherwise had."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Life or death for many': Sydney-based Palestinian describes situation in Gaza

children.content: By Declan Bowring, ABC Radio Sydney
A Sydney-based Palestinian with family in Gaza says it's a matter of life and death for her relatives.
Ramia Abdo Sultan told ABC Radio Sydney Mornings she had relatives sheltering at a UN-run school, which was taking 6,000 people despite only having capacity for 1,500 people.

props.alt: A woman in a headscarf and a man wearing a polo shirt stand together

children.content: Ramia Abdo Sultan and Forat Sultan.
(ABC News: Fletcher Yeung)
She says food is also scarce, with people at the shelter receiving three loaves of bread and three cups of water a day.
"In my lifetime, for all I've known it, I've never seen this unfold," Ms Abdo Sultan said.
"It's a situation of literally life or death for many who are surviving the massacre."
Ms Abdo Sultan said she has patchy contact with her relatives who need to find solar-generated power to charge their phones.
Ms Abdo Sultan says Australians who can leave Gaza have tried to exit through the Rafa crossing into Egypt but have not been able to get through multiple times.
"They've tried multiple times to leave … only to wait a couple of hours and to be left with no option but to return," Ms Abdo Sultan said.
"They feel like they have not had the same level of support and attention that anyone else around the world would have otherwise had."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden will make a rare prime-time national address pitching spending billions on Israel and Ukraine. The speech will happen at 10am AEST. "We are at a global inflection point that is bigger than party or politics," he wrote in a social media post.

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: For the first time in more than 18 months, ANZ has cut the ongoing interest rate it pays on its online savings account, by 0.10 percentage points. It's the first time any of the big four banks has cuts rates on a savings account during this time. It means existing customers who have had their account for more than three months will now be earning just 1.5% on any deposits. Sally Tindall from comparison website RateCity says its database shows more banks are now cutting rates than hiking them. In the past two months, 14% of banks have cut as least one savings rate. "The cash rate has risen by 4 percentage points in the last year and a half. If the RBA moves in the next few months, it is likely to be up, not down, and yet, ANZ is cutting the ongoing Online Saver rate from a paltry 1.6% to an even more ridiculous 1.5%," she said. She says the big four banks' online saver rates are low. "At a time when every dollar makes a difference, customers should make sure their savings rate starts with a '5' not a '1'."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ cuts rates on savings account

children.content: For the first time in more than 18 months,
ANZ has cut the ongoing interest rate it pays on its online savings account
, by 0.10 percentage points.
It's the first time any of the big four banks has cuts rates on a savings account during this time.
It means existing customers who have had their account for more than three months will now be earning just 1.5% on any deposits.
Sally Tindall from comparison website RateCity says its database shows more banks are now cutting rates than hiking them.
In the past two months, 14% of banks have cut as least one savings rate.

"The cash rate has risen by 4 percentage points in the last year and a half. If the RBA moves in the next few months, it is likely to be up, not down, and yet, ANZ is cutting the ongoing Online Saver rate from a paltry 1.6% to an even more ridiculous 1.5%," she said.
She says the big four banks' online saver rates are low.
"At a time when every dollar makes a difference, customers should make sure their savings rate starts with a '5' not a '1'."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The gold price in Aussie dollars hit a record $3,138 an ounce this morning. It comes as the Australian dollar is buying $US63.3 (at 9.30am AEDT). When calculating the price of gold in currencies other than the US dollar, the exchange rate becomes vital. The price of gold has risen in the past week due to its status as a "safe haven" during uncertain times. Interestingly, the old record of $3,073 was set less than a week ago! It's been to the benefit of listed Australian gold miners, which pay their operating costs in Australian dollars, before selling gold in US dollars.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian dollar gold price hits record high
